Award.AwardTitle: Impact of Scaffolding Characteristics and Study Quality on Learner Outcomes in STEM Education: A Meta-analysis

Directorate.LongName: Direct For Education and Human Resources

Award.AbstractNarration:
This two-year synthesis project, led by researchers at Utah State University, focuses on the use of scaffolding in STEM learning in formal and informal settings. Scaffolding is support that helps students engage in and gain skill at tasks that are beyond their unassisted capabilities. The project uses meta-analysis to determine the influence of scaffold characteristics, study and assessment instrument quality, and assessment type on cognitive outcomes in K-Adult STEM education.

Preparing all students to address fundamental STEM problems is central to preparing effective citizens for the 21st century. Combined with scaffolding, inquiry-based approaches in STEM education can lead to this goal. A current lack of a comprehensive assessment of scaffolding characteristics hinders (a) scaffolding adoption by STEM instructors and administrators and (b) scaffolding design by instructional designers.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Intellectual merit. The project was designed to synthesize published research on cognitive outcomes resulting from the use of computer-based scaffolding within problem-centered instruction in STEM education (K-12, college, graduate/professional, and adult). Three different types of meta-analyses were completed – traditional, between-subjects meta-analysis; Bayesian network (within-subjects) meta-analysis; and Bayesian between-subjects meta-analysis. The first traditional meta-analysis synthesized 144 studies (Belland, Walker, Kim, & Lefler, 2017). The overall effect size of scaffolding was g = 0.46, and scaffolding had strong effects across participant populations (elementary to adult) and there was no difference in effect size based on scaffold customization or scaffold customization basis. The second traditional meta-analysis found that when scaffolding was used by pairs or larger groups, effect sizes were larger when the scaffolding did not contain support for collaboration. The first Bayesian network meta-analysis examined contexts of scaffolding use using coding of 49 studies and Markov Chain Monte Carlo (MCMC) simulations; pre-post gains were strongest for students with learning disabilities (g = 3.13) and English Language Learners (g = 0.92) (Belland, Walker, & Kim, 2017). The second Bayesian network meta-analysis examined scaffolding characteristics using coding of 47 studies and MCMC simulations; scaffolding that did not customize over time led to stronger pre-post gains than scaffolding that faded, added, or both faded and added (Walker et al., 2016). The Bayesian meta-analysis indicated that, within problem-based learning, scaffolding that both fades and adds leads to the strongest effect sizes (Kim, Belland, & Walker, 2018).

Broader impacts. The project has important implications both for scaffolding and for methodology. To our knowledge, this project is the first that applied Bayesian network meta-analysis, and one of the first to use Bayesian meta-analysis with mean difference, in educational research. We published supplemental videos, Winbugs code, and our coding dataset along with our Bayesian network-meta-analysis published in Review of Educational Research to help other researchers learn how to conduct such a meta-analysis, in addition to furthering the important goal of open science. Furthermore, scaffolding techniques were disseminated to teachers and teacher educators. One dissertation was completed, and another will be conducted shortly, involving research supported by this grant. Two PhD students and three undergraduate students have been involved in the research. Two of the undergraduate students presented some of their work on the project as first author at the Annual Meeting of the American Educational Research Association – a rare accomplishment for an undergraduate student.

Publications resulting from the award. This work has produced three peer-reviewed journal articles (Belland, Walker, & Kim, 2017; Belland, Walker, Kim, et al., 2017; Kim et al., 2018) - two in Review of Educational Research and one in Educational Psychology Review, one book (Belland, 2017), and four journal manuscripts.
